sentence: ” Originally, the official story of how President Kennedy sustained his throat wound was that a bullet fragment coursed downward through his head and emerged in the front of his throat, and that remained as the official story until the Warren Commission came out with its report in September 1964, in which they claimed that the throat wound was an exit wound for a bullet that allegedly entered the back of the President’s neck.

Connally was interviewed for CNN’s Larry King Live on November 22, 2003, the fortieth anniversary of the assassination, and when she was asked about the bullet allegedly passing through President Kennedy and wounding her husband, she stated, “Well, let me ask you this, do you think a bullet that went through the President’s neck can hang there in air between the two seats while John turned to the right, turned to the left and came back.

” He testified that to think that the same bullet that caused President Kennedy’s throat wound also caused the massive head injury in back “required some straining of the imagination,” but the consensus of the doctors was obviously that the throat wound was an entrance wound, and the massive wound at the back of the head was an exit wound.

” FBI Agents Sibert and O’Neill wrote in their report that, during the autopsy, Humes “located an opening which appeared to be a bullet hole which was below the shoulders,” and that Humes then probed President Kennedy’s back wound with his finger, “at which time it was determined that the trajectory of the missile entering at this point had entered at a downward position of 45 to 60 degrees.

” Since the back wound was lower than the throat wound, and the official story was that President Kennedy had been shot from behind, the only possible explanation that could be offered for the throat wound was that it was caused by a fragment from a headshot fired from behind.

” Sibert and O’Neill were obviously not called to testify because their testimony would directly contradict the new cover up story that was being formulated, the story that President Kennedy was shot in the back of the neck and that the bullet emerged from his throat.

” On March 12, 1964, the day that Specter interviewed Sibert and O’Neill, Assistant FBI Director Alex Rosen wrote a memorandum stating that Specter’s interview with Sibert and O’Neill was an “interrogation,” and one of the questions that Specter interrogated Sibert and O’Neill about was, “What was the reaction of the examiners upon being notified that a bullet had been found on a stretcher used at Dallas?

Humes stated that in the “telephone communication,” Perry informed him that there had been a bullet wound where the tracheotomy had been performed, and Humes allegedly deduced that it was an exit wound for the bullet that struck President Kennedy lower down in the back.

Peters testified to the Warren Commission and he was asked about “discussions with the other doctors who attended President Kennedy,” whereupon he stated, “The initial impression that we had was that perhaps the wound in the neck, the anterior part of the neck, was an entrance wound.

” As a result of not knowing how many bullets President Kennedy was struck by, the doctors thought that it was possible that after the bullet entered the throat, it struck “the anterior vertebral body,” and then went “into the skull itself, exiting out the back, to produce the massive injury in the head.

They obviously weren’t going to acknowledge that he had been shot from the front, and they didn’t want to make the claim that a bullet blew off the top right side of his head while a fragment from that same bullet coursed downward through his head and caused the throat wound.

” And Rankin continued, “With the elevation the shot must have come from, it seems quite apparent now, since we have the picture of where the bullet entered in the back, that the bullet entered below the shoulder blade to the right of the backbone, which is below the place where the picture shows the bullet came out in the neckband of the shirt in front.

McClelland stated that it was only the “later reports” and “all the circumstances surrounding the assassination” that caused the doctors to change their original perspective that the throat wound was an entrance wound and the wound at the back of the head was an exit wound.

” The Warren Commission’s Executive Session on January 27, 1964 is the only place where they acknowledge that, after the assassination, there was an official position that either a fragment from the headshot caused the throat wound, or that the throat wound was an entrance wound.

” FBI Agent Frank O’Neill testified to the Assassination Records Review Board in 1997 that he and Sibert had spoken with Warren Commission staffer Arlen Specter about what had taken place during the autopsy, and O’Neill’s affidavit to the House Assassinations Committee back in 1978, he stated that he had been “interviewed at length” by Arlen Specter.
